Glass eel and elver trades expanded in the twentieth century, linking Atlantic and East Asian markets. Dams, habitat loss, and overfishing later reduced stocks. Hatchery breakthroughs remain limited, so aquaculture depends on wild seed. Restoration efforts focus on fish passage, wetland recovery, and trade controls. Eel culture and cuisine continue to shape regional identities and economies.

name: Caviar
description: Caviar is salted roe from sturgeons native to the Caspian, Black Sea, and major Eurasian rivers. Russian and Persian fisheries supplied courts, embassies, and luxury markets from the early modern period onward. Nineteenth-century exports expanded through Astrakhan and Baku. Beluga, osetra, and sevruga became standard grades with strict handling and salting methods. European hotels and diplomatic tables prized caviar as a high-status food. Overfishing, river regulation, and pollution diminished wild sturgeon in the twentieth century. International controls and trade labeling followed. Aquaculture developed to meet demand and reduce pressure on wild stocks. Historical ledgers, tariff schedules, and culinary guides document shifting sources, grades, and techniques that defined the trade from imperial monopolies to regulated modern production.

name: Carp
description: Carp were domesticated for food and pond culture across Eurasia. In China, integrated rice–fish systems and pond polyculture stabilized yields and diversified diets. Song and Ming treatises recorded breeding and feeding practices. Medieval European monasteries managed carp ponds to supply fasting tables and urban markets. Common carp spread across Central Europe by the early modern period. Japan developed ornamental koi strains during the Edo period, elevating carp in garden and estate culture. Nineteenth- and twentieth-century introductions carried carp to North America and Australasia. The fish became both a food resource and an invasive species in some waters. Modern aquaculture uses selective breeding, formulated feeds, and polyculture to maintain production while addressing ecological concerns.

name: Pearls
description: Natural pearls formed in oysters and mussels were prized in many civilizations. The Persian Gulf and Gulf of Mannar supported extensive fisheries serving Near Eastern and South Asian markets. Roman, Byzantine, and later European elites accumulated pearl jewelry and regalia. Spanish colonial fleets drew pearls from Caribbean banks near Margarita and Cubagua in the sixteenth century. Diving relied on skilled labor facing decompression and predation risks. Merchant networks routed pearls through Gulf ports and Mediterranean fairs. In the early twentieth century, cultured pearl techniques in Japan shifted the market and reduced pressure on wild beds. Natural fisheries persisted at smaller scales under regulation. Archaeological finds and court inventories trace the enduring role of pearls in adornment and high-value trade.

name: Gold
description: Gold is a dense, corrosion-resistant metal valued for durability and luster. Ancient Egyptians used it for funerary masks, temple fittings, and court jewelry. Lydian and Greek coinage standardized gold as a monetary metal. The Roman aureus and Byzantine solidus circulated across Eurasia. West African fields supplied trans-Saharan trade that enriched Ghana and Mali. Sixteenth-century Spanish conquest drew bullion from Caribbean and Andean realms, altering European finance. Gold rushes in California, Australia, and the Klondike spurred migration and frontier economies. Gold leaf, gilding, and fine chasing shaped courtly art from Europe to Mughal India. The nineteenth- and twentieth-century gold standard tied currencies to bullion reserves. Central banks continue to hold gold as a reserve asset and crisis hedge.

name: Silver
description: Silver is a ductile, reflective metal widely employed for coinage and fine wares. Classical economies relied on Athenian Laurion and Roman Iberian mines to mint drachmas and denarii. The Spanish discovery of Potosí and Andean lodes in the sixteenth century produced unprecedented output. Silver pesos, the “piece of eight,” became a global medium of exchange. Manila galleons moved American silver to Asia, where Chinese tax demands in silver drove sustained flows. The European Price Revolution reflected bullion influx and monetary expansion. Mints shifted standards between bimetallism and gold ratios in the nineteenth century. Silversmithing framed social display from Islamic courts to European guilds. Photography, electrical contacts, and medical alloys added modern uses, though coinage declined with fiat currency.

name: Amber
description: Amber is fossilized tree resin prized for warm color, polish, and ease of carving. Neolithic and Bronze Age Europe produced beads and pendants found in graves and hoards. The Baltic coast supplied the major source, feeding the Amber Road into the Mediterranean. Mycenaean, Etruscan, and Roman elites collected and traded worked pieces. Roman authors attributed protective and medicinal virtues to amber. Medieval workshops in the Baltic cities fashioned rosaries and reliquaries. Early modern centers in Gdańsk and Königsberg created luxury cabinets and liturgical objects. The eighteenth-century Amber Room exemplified princely patronage. Scientific interest grew with electrical properties noted by classical writers and later refined in early physics. Trade persisted into modern tourism and artisan industries along the Baltic littoral.

name: Emerald
description: Emerald is the green gem variety of beryl colored by trace chromium or vanadium. Ancient Egyptian sources at Wadi Sikait and Wadi el-Hudi supplied Hellenistic and Roman markets. Writers linked the stone to court fashion in Ptolemaic and Roman settings. After 1530, Spanish control of the Muzo and Chivor mines in the Colombian Andes shifted global supply. Seville, Lisbon, and Goa funneled stones into Iberian, Mughal, and Safavid workshops. Mughal jewelers mounted large cabochons in turban ornaments, daggers, and reliquaries. Renaissance and Baroque Europe favored carved intaglios and elaborate gold settings. Nineteenth-century gemology improved cutting and grading. Modern demand relies on Colombian, Zambian, and Brazilian fields, with oiling and resin treatments standard in the trade.

name: Marble
description: Marble is a metamorphic limestone valued for fine grain and polish, enabling durable sculpture and architecture. Quarries at Paros and Mount Pentelikon supplied Classical Greece for temples and statues. Rome exploited Carrara, known as Luna marble, for imperial projects and portraiture. Medieval builders reused antique blocks while maintaining local quarrying. Renaissance artists, including Michelangelo, carved major works from Carrara, such as David and the Pietà. The Ottoman and Mughal courts employed white marble for palatial and funerary architecture, notably the Taj Mahal using Makrana stone. European neoclassicism and American civic architecture adopted marble for facades and interiors. Modern quarrying uses wire saws and diamond tools, extending applications to cladding, flooring, and restoration.

name: Diamonds
description: Diamond is crystalline carbon with exceptional hardness and refractive properties. Early mining in India’s Golconda fields supplied the ancient and medieval luxury trade. Islamic and European courts prized uncut and table-cut stones. Cutting advances in the Low Countries during the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries improved brilliance. Brazilian alluvial deposits overtook Indian output in the eighteenth century. South African kimberlite pipes at Kimberley and beyond transformed supply and mining technology in the late nineteenth century. Cartelized marketing shaped prices and branding in the twentieth century. Industrial diamonds and synthetic abrasives enabled precision cutting and drilling. Scientific work on high pressure and high temperature produced synthetic stones, later joined by chemical vapor deposition for gem and industrial use.

name: Lapis Lazuli
description: Lapis lazuli is a blue metamorphic rock composed chiefly of lazurite with accessory minerals. The historic source lay in Badakhshan in present-day Afghanistan. Mesopotamian and Egyptian artisans carved beads, amulets, and inlays, including elements in elite burials and royal regalia. Cylinder seals and Egyptian funerary masks used contrasting gold and blue. Greco-Roman traders moved the stone via Near Eastern routes. In medieval and Renaissance Europe, lapis was ground to produce ultramarine, the costliest blue pigment for panel painting and manuscript illumination. Venetian and Flemish workshops reserved it for high-status commissions. Trade traveled along Silk Road and Levantine channels. Synthetic ultramarine in the nineteenth century reduced pigment costs, but gem use of lapis continued in jewelry and hardstone carving.

name: Turquoise
description: Turquoise is a blue to green copper-aluminum phosphate valued for its opaque color and fine polish. Ancient Egyptian mines in Sinai and Persian deposits near Nishapur supplied early jewels and inlays. The material circulated through Anatolian and Mediterranean trade into medieval Europe, giving the stone its French name. In Iran and Central Asia, craftsmen set turquoise in weapon hilts, mosque fittings, and court jewelry. Pre-Columbian Mesoamerica produced mosaics and ceremonial objects for Aztec and Mixtec elites. In the American Southwest, Puebloan, Navajo, and Zuni artisans integrated turquoise with silverwork and ceremonial regalia. Qing workshops combined turquoise with jade and gold for court ornaments. Stabilization and reconstitution techniques expanded modern use as high-grade sources declined.

name: Jade
description: Jade encompasses two tough ornamental stones, nephrite and jadeite. Neolithic cultures in China shaped nephrite into polished axes, bi discs, and cong tubes used in ritual settings. The material acquired enduring prestige in Chinese court culture, culminating in Qing virtuoso carvings. In Mesoamerica, jadeite from Guatemala’s Motagua Valley furnished Olmec and Maya figurines, earspools, and regalia linked to royal display. Polynesian and Māori artisans fashioned nephrite, known as pounamu, into adzes and heirloom ornaments. European Neolithic societies distributed alpine nephrite axes over long distances. The nineteenth century brought significant jadeite trade from Burma to China. Modern markets distinguish sources and treatments, with imperial green jadeite commanding the highest prices.

name: Quartz
description: Quartz is a common silicate mineral occurring in many varieties, including colorless rock crystal and colored chalcedonies. Prehistoric communities flaked and ground quartz for tools and projectile points. Rock crystal vessels and amulets appear in Greco-Roman and medieval contexts. High-purity silica sand became a key input for glassmaking in Roman, Venetian, and Bohemian industries. Carvers shaped crystal reliquaries and lens-like ornaments for churches and courts. Scientific study identified piezoelectric properties in the late nineteenth century, enabling resonators and precision timing in the twentieth century. Quartz sands support foundry molds and ceramics. Gem varieties such as amethyst and carnelian served jewelry markets across Asia and Europe, with extensive workshops in India and the Islamic world.
